case_title: SHIV NARAIN CHAUDHARI vs COMMISSIONER OF WEALTH TAX, LUCKNOW
complaint_summary: The appellant, a Hindu undivided family, claimed exemption under Section 5(1)(iv) of the Wealth Tax Act, 1957, for properties bearing Municipal Nos. 92, 92-A (Darbhanga Castle), and 17/33 (Mahatma Gandhi Marg, Allahabad). The Wealth Tax Officer exempted only one property (No. 92). Successive appeals upheld this decision.
investigation_summary: The Wealth Tax Officer determined that properties bearing separate municipal door numbers (92 and 92-A) were independent units and not eligible for exemption as one house. The Tribunal upheld this view, emphasizing the separate construction years and municipal assessments.
judgment_summary: The court ruled that properties bearing Municipal Nos. 92 and 92-A constituted one house and were exempt under Section 5(1)(iv) of the Wealth Tax Act, 1957. However, the property at Municipal No. 17/33 was not exempt. The decision partly favored the appellant and partly the respondent.
Decision_or_verdict: Partly in favor of the appellant; Municipal Nos. 92 and 92-A exempt, but Municipal No. 17/33 not exempt.
legal_arguments: Shri R. K. Gulati argued that Municipal Nos. 92 and 92-A formed one house and were exclusively used for residential purposes, qualifying for exemption.
Shri Ashok Gupta contended that the Tribunal's decision was correct, emphasizing the independent construction and municipal assessments of the properties.

assets.description: Building bearing Municipal Nos. 92 and 92-A, Darbhanga Castle, Allahabad
Building bearing Municipal No. 17/33, Mahatma Gandhi Marg, Allahabad

citations: Annicola Investments Ltd. v. Minister of Housing and Local Government [1965] 3 A.1 ER 850
Benabo v. Mayor, Aldermen and Burgesses of the Borough of Wood Green [1945] 2 A.1 ER 162
Okereke v. Borough of Brent [1966] 1 A.1 ER 150
key_issues: Whether Municipal Nos. 92 and 92-A constitute one house for exemption under Section 5(1)(iv).
Whether Municipal No. 17/33 qualifies for exemption under Section 5(1)(iv).

maxims.Interpretation of 'house' in statutory c: The meaning of 'house' must be construed in relation to the context, object, and purpose of the statute.

legal_terms.Hindu Undivided Family: A joint family structure recognized under Indian law.
legal_terms.Net Wealth: Total assets minus liabilities for wealth tax purposes.

words_and_phrases.Unity of Structure: Physical and functional integration of a building.
words_and_phrases.Exclusive Use: Utilization solely for residential purposes by the owner.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around the interpretation of 'house' under Section 5(1)(iv) of the Wealth Tax Act, 1957. The court ruled that Municipal Nos. 92 and 92-A constituted one house and were exempt from wealth tax, while Municipal No. 17/33 was not exempt. The judgment emphasizes the importance of unity of structure and exclusive residential use in determining tax exemptions.
